class_notes:
FR 331 All Too Real: Tales and Fairytales 
C. Nouvet / T Th 1:00-2:15pm
Content:  Literature may ask us to cross into another world, another space and time which seem utterly disconnected from reality. Far from being simply unreal, this other world points in fact to another kind of reality: the psychic reality of fantasies and desires.  It is the various facets of this psychic reality (beyond or below what passes for "reality") that the genre of the "conte" explores as it moves from the world of Celtic legends, to the fairy tales of Perrault, and finally to the uncanny and anxiety-ridden experiences staged in 19th century "contes fantastiques." 
 
Texts may include
Charles Perrault: Contes [selections]
Gustave Flaubert: Trois contes
Guy de Maupassant: Contes fantastiques [selections]
Villiers de l'Isle-Adam: Contes cruels [selections]
Gautier: Contes et r√©cits fantastiques [selections]
course_description: This course focuses on the development of key concepts, ideas, or movements across historical periods and cultural contexts. By retracing their elaboration it serves to highlight continuities and discontinuities in the historical development of French and Francophone literatures and cultures.
prerequisites: FREN 310 or FREN_OX 310 and FREN 314 or FREN_OX 314 or equivalent transfer credit as prerequisite.
